turns.content: What are some effective online communication tools for remote teams?

1. Video conferencing tools like Zoom, Skype, Google Meet, or Microsoft Teams
2. Instant messaging platforms like Slack or Microsoft Teams
3. Project management tools like Asana, Trello, or Basecamp
4. Audio messaging apps like Voxer or Slack
5. Virtual whiteboards like Miro or Google Jamboard
6. Screen sharing tools like Screenleap or Join.me
7. Email and email automation tools like Mailchimp or Sendinblue
8. Cloud storage and file sharing platforms like Dropbox or Google Drive.
Do you have any recommendations specifically for remote team collaboration on design projects?

Sure! Here are some online communication tools that can help remote teams collaborate on design projects:

1. Figma - a collaborative design platform for teams where designers can work together on designs in real-time. 2. InVision - a design collaboration platform that allows teams to share design files, prototypes, and collaborate on feedback. 3. Sketch - a design tool that allows designers to collaborate on designs in real-time, share their work with team members, and receive feedback. 4. Marvel - a design platform that allows teams to create and share designs, prototypes, and collaborate on feedback. 5. Abstract - a version control platform for designs, where teams can collaborate on designs, track changes and provide feedback. 6. Adobe Creative Cloud - a suite of design and collaboration tools that includes Adobe XD, Photoshop, Illustrator, and more. 7. Zeplin - a platform that connects designers and developers to collaborate on design assets like style guides, component libraries, and code snippets. These tools enable designers and their team members to work seamlessly, share files, and give feedback in real-time regardless of their physical location.
These design collaboration tools sound great. Which one would you recommend for a small, remote design team with a limited budget?

If you have a small remote design team with a limited budget, I would recommend Figma or InVision as they offer free or affordable pricing plans with enough features to help you collaborate effectively. 

Figma is a cloud-based design tool with a lot of collaborative features such as real-time design collaboration, commenting, and chat. The basic plan is free and allows you to work on up to three design files for free, and advanced plans start at $12 per editor per month. 

InVision provides a full suite of design and collaboration features including prototyping, inspect, and handoff. It has a free plan for a single project, while the paid plans start at $7.95 per user per month. It also offers a 90-day free trial for its paid plans.

Both of these tools offer design collaboration features and have a user-friendly interface. I would suggest trying them out and then choosing based on your team's preferences and needs.
Can these design collaboration tools integrate with project management tools like Asana?

Yes, both Figma and InVision can integrate with Asana or other project management tools to help you keep your design workflow organized.

Figma can integrate with Asana using third-party services like Zapier or Integromat that enable you to instantly move your Figma comments and feedback to Asana's task list, create new Asana tasks from Figma designs, and vice versa.

InVision also can integrate with Asana and other project management tools like Trello, Slack, Basecamp, and JIRA. This integration enables you to create tasks, link to designs, and assign design tasks directly from Asana, keeping everyone on the same page and driving your project forward.

Overall, integrating your design tools with your project management tools can help you streamline your design workflow, optimize collaboration, and improve team communication.
